questions.question: What is the main goal of developing single-component semiconductors with intrinsic UV–SWIR photoresponse?
questions.answer: The main goal is to reduce complexity and cost of photodetectors or to promote power conversion efficiency of solar cells by extending photoresponse ranges of semiconductors to the entire ultraviolet–visible (UV)–shortwave near-infrared (SWIR) region.

questions.question: What are viologen compounds known for in the context of organic-based semiconductors?
questions.answer: Viologen compounds are known for their remarkable absorption in the visible region after receiving electrons and forming radicals, and broader absorption is predictable if they are consolidated through infinite π-stacking.

questions.question: What approach was used to address the issues of low photoconversion rate and stability of radicals in viologen compounds?
questions.answer: A cyanide-bridged layer-directed intercalation approach was used to effectively address the issues of low photoconversion rate and stability of radicals in viologen compounds.

questions.question: What is the significance of the cyanide-bridged layer-directed intercalation approach in the development of viologen-based semiconductors?
questions.answer: The cyanide-bridged layer-directed intercalation approach is significant because it enables the construction of viologen-based 2D semiconductors with intrinsic absorption bands covering the entire UV–SWIR range, leading to photocurrent response in the wavelength range of at least 355−2400 nm.

questions.question: True or False: The photoresponsive range of the as-prepared crystalline sample of the viologen-based semiconductor is in ∼280–420 nm.
questions.answer: True

questions.question: What was the outcome of photo/thermo-induced coloration in the viologen-based semiconductors?
questions.answer: The outcome of photo/thermo-induced coloration was the generation of long-lived radical products and the exhibition of intrinsic photoresponsive bands covering the UV–SWIR region.

questions.question: True or False: The cyanide-bridged layer-directed intercalation approach resulted in the loss of water stability for the viologen-based semiconductors.
questions.answer: False

questions.question: What was the role of thermal annealing in the photo/thermo-induced coloration process?
questions.answer: Thermal annealing played a role in generating stronger electron absorption bands and ESR signals compared to photoinduced samples, indicating a higher conversion rate of radicals.

questions.question: True or False: The viologen-based semiconductors showed photocurrent response only in the visible light range.
questions.answer: False

questions.question: What was the record set by the viologen-based semiconductors in terms of photocurrent response?
questions.answer: The viologen-based semiconductors set a record by showing intrinsic photocurrent response in the range of at least 355–2400 nm, exceeding all reported values for known single-component organic-based semiconductors.

questions.question: True or False: The cyanide-bridged layer-directed intercalation approach does not contribute to the planarization of viologen cations.
questions.answer: False

questions.question: What was the main challenge in using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy to prove the direction of electron transfer in viologen-based semiconductors?
questions.answer: The main challenge was that the paramagnetic metals in the semiconductors are easily reduced by X-ray-induced electrons, bringing difficulty for analysis.

questions.question: True or False: The viologen-based semiconductors were unstable in the presence of oxygen.
questions.answer: False

questions.question: What potential applications are envisioned for the viologen-based semiconductors developed using the cyanide-bridged layer-directed intercalation approach?
questions.answer: The potential applications envisioned include broadband photodetectors and solar cells.

questions.question: True or False: The cyanide-bridged layer-directed intercalation approach led to a decrease in the photoresponsive range of the viologen-based semiconductors.
questions.answer: False

questions.question: What was the role of Cl− and CN− ions in the electron transfer process within the viologen-based semiconductors?
questions.answer: Both Cl− and CN− ions may act as effective electron donors for viologen cations, contributing to the electron transfer process.

questions.question: True or False: The viologen-based semiconductors developed using the cyanide-bridged layer-directed intercalation approach are only active under thermal conditions.
questions.answer: False

questions.question: What was the significance of the broad bands in the range of ∼900–3000 nm observed for all photo/thermo-induced samples of the viologen-based semiconductors?
questions.answer: The broad bands in the range of ∼900–3000 nm were significant as they were attributed to the contribution of π-stacked MQ aggregates, indicating the extension of absorption range to cover the whole UV–SWIR region.

questions.question: True or False: The cyanide-bridged layer-directed intercalation approach resulted in the viologen-based semiconductors being sensitive only to UV light.
questions.answer: False

questions.question: What future improvements are planned for the viologen-based semiconductors developed using the cyanide-bridged layer-directed intercalation approach?
questions.answer: Future improvements include enhancing electrical properties such as conductivity and photocurrent gain, extending photoresponse bands to the mid-IR region, and exploring effective methods to construct optical devices.
